channel.title: Easyrsc
channel.description: I followed instructions downloading jdk and setting up ant/evironment variables and still it doesn't work I would post a picture of what is showing up but idk how lol ... any idea to as what might going wrong?.

item.title: Easyrsc
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Captain Jack Sparrow, post:19, topic:439604”]i have jdk. thank you, i fixed the error of tools.jar from bein found. but my compile.bat still doesnt like me and cant find java.exe. it says

taskkill /F /IM java.exe in my compile file btw.

when i pasted my ip in the server file like you said and tried to compile it thats when it said java.exe not found. and it still builded. then i ran server and i get errors like:

[Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
[Error] [Ljava.lang.StackTraceElement;@66de609
[Other] CleanRSC Shutting Down…

edit: i then added localhost back to the server file and i compiled and got a message saying:
SUCCESS: The process “java.exe” with PID 3288 has been terminated.

i get little msgs also saying recompile with -xlint unchecked files blah blah etc…[/quote]
You gotta find your IPv4 ip, go to start->run->cmd, or if you use vista/7 go to start menu and search cmd., then write ipconfig and copy the IPv4 address and put it in ur server.

The message you’re getting about java task not found, is because it looks for current running java tasks to destroy and if there’s none running it just informs that it couldn’t find any. xEnt added it on EasyRSC because when you close the ‘black window’, RSCD keeps running in the background untill you kill the task from task manager(Ctrl + Alt + Del).

In short: Just ignore the message.

Read full topic

i have jdk. thank you, i fixed the error of tools.jar from bein found. but my compile.bat still doesnt like me and cant find java.exe. it says

taskkill /F /IM java.exe in my compile file btw.

when i pasted my ip in the server file like you said and tried to compile it thats when it said java.exe not found. and it still builded. then i ran server and i get errors like:

[Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
[Error] [Ljava.lang.StackTraceElement;@66de609
[Other] CleanRSC Shutting Down…

edit: i then added localhost back to the server file and i compiled and got a message saying:
SUCCESS: The process “java.exe” with PID 3288 has been terminated.

i get little msgs also saying recompile with -xlint unchecked files blah blah etc…

Read full topic

item.title: Easyrsc
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

Captain Jack Sparrow:

the process java.exe is not found… wtf? i tried to edit localhost to my ip in that server class file when i compiled it fucked up now it wont even run the server it just builds and completes o.O i cant get a chance to read it cause it goes to fast.

To see the error message or what ever it’s saying, go to your apache location, and edit ant.bat, then go to the end of the file and put ‘pause’ after :omega:.

I’m pretty sure it’s the message that tells you that it couldn’t find the tools.jar,
If you haven’t already, Go to C:/Program Files/Java/jdk_(version)/lib/ and locate tools.jar, copy it, then go to
C:/Program Files/Java/jre6/lib and paste it there.

If you don’t have JDK installed yet, go download and install it.

Read full topic

item.title: Easyrsc
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“BorigTheDwarf, post:12, topic:439604”][quote author=-Nothing link=topic=542297.msg3978405#msg3978405 date=1334946756]

Oh right so sessionid means it made a connection?

Yes, for the server to have any response at all when someone tries to log in the port must be forwarded or they must be connecting via localhost. Because of this, we must assume that in this case there is something wrong with the login protocol or the client or something wrong with both of them. E.g. this is most likely what would happen if you tried to login to a 377 server with a 697 (or whatever) client.

THIS IS RSC, NOT RS2.

Does that change anything?

If you have no fucking idea how RSC client works, don’t try to argue with us.
[/quote]

I have an idea about how computers and the internet work and I can tell you that a connection cannot be made if there is nothing to receive the connection (I.e. if a port isn’t forwarded). So please, STFU. This is the case if it is RSC, RS2, Farcry whatever the fuck game you want to play.[/quote]
Let me quote my last post, so maybe you would understand.

-Nothing:

If you have no fucking idea how RSC client works, don’t try to argue with us.

Read full topic

Oh right so sessionid means it made a connection?

Yes, for the server to have any response at all when someone tries to log in the port must be forwarded or they must be connecting via localhost. Because of this, we must assume that in this case there is something wrong with the login protocol or the client or something wrong with both of them. E.g. this is most likely what would happen if you tried to login to a 377 server with a 697 (or whatever) client.

THIS IS RSC, NOT RS2.

Does that change anything?
[/quote]
If you have no fucking idea how RSC client works, don’t try to argue with us.[/quote]

I have an idea about how computers and the internet work and I can tell you that a connection cannot be made if there is nothing to receive the connection (I.e. if a port isn’t forwarded). So please, STFU. This is the case if it is RSC, RS2, Farcry whatever the fuck game you want to play.

Read full topic

item.title: Easyrsc
item.dc:creator: @BorigTheDwarf BorigTheDwarf
item.description:
@BorigTheDwarf wrote:

freaky5000, I think you should stop helping people when you clearly have no idea what you are doing. If he hadn’t port forwarded (or wasn’t connecting via local host) the connection would never have been made for it to disconnect.

I would say this problem is probably caused by the client sending the wrong packets on login. Are you using the client which came with the server?

Read full topic
